content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 6 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds,” and the heading for row 2 is “f of t, in gallons per second.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; f of t is 0. Column 2. t is 60; f of t is 0.1. Column 3. t is 90; f of t is 0.15. Column 4. t is 120; f of t is 0.1. Column 5. t is 135; f of t is 0.05. Column 6. t is 150; f of t is 0." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>60</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>120</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>135</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>150</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(gallons per second)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.05</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

A customer at a gas station is pumping gasoline into a gas tank. The rate of flow of gasoline is modeled by a differentiable function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, where <math alttext="f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in gallons per second and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is measured in seconds since pumping began. Selected values of <math alttext="f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> are given in the table.

(a) Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from 60 to 135, of, f of t, d t " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>60</mn><mn>135</mn></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem. Use a right Riemann sum with the three subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 60 comma 90, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mn>60</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>90</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 90 comma 120, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mn>90</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>120</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 120 comma 135, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>135</mn><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math> to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 60 to 135, of, f of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>60</mn><mn>135</mn></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.
You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure shows a 2 row table with 6 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds,” and the heading for row 2 is “f of t, in gallons per second.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0; f of t is 0. Column 2. t is 60; f of t is 0.1. Column 3. t is 90; f of t is 0.15. Column 4. t is 120; f of t is 0.1. Column 5. t is 135; f of t is 0.05. Column 6. t is 150; f of t is 0." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>60</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>120</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>135</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>150</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(gallons per second)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.05</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

A customer at a gas station is pumping gasoline into a gas tank. The rate of flow of gasoline is modeled by a differentiable function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, where <math alttext="f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is measured in gallons per second and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is measured in seconds since pumping began. Selected values of <math alttext="f of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> are given in the table.

(a) Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from 60 to 135, of, f of t, d t " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>60</mn><mn>135</mn></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem. Use a right Riemann sum with the three subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 60 comma 90, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mn>60</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>90</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 90 comma 120, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><mn>90</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>120</mn></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 120 comma 135, close bracket" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>135</mn><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math> to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 60 to 135, of, f of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>60</mn><mn>135</mn></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mstyle></math>.

(b) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math>, for <math alttext="60 less than c, less than 120" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn><mo><</mo><mi>c</mi><mo><</mo><mn>120</mn></math>, such that <math alttext="f prime of c, equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>c</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> ?  Justify your answer.

(c) The rate of flow of gasoline, in gallons per second, can also be modeled by <math alttext="g of t equals, open parenthesis, the fraction t over 500, close parenthesis, times the cosine of, open parenthesis, open parenthesis, the fraction t over 120, close parenthesis, squared, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>=</mo><mfenced><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>t</mi><mn>500</mn></mfrac></mstyle></mfenced><mi>cos</mi><mfenced><msup><mfenced><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>t</mi><mn>120</mn></mfrac></mstyle></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup></mfenced></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>150</mn></math>. Using this model, find the average rate of flow of gasoline over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>150</mn></math>. Show the setup for your calculations.

(d) Using the model <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math> defined in part (c), find the value of <math alttext="g prime of 140" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>g</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>140</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Interpret the meaning of your answer in the context of the problem.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
